{{refimprove|date=July 2018}} [[File:3 PAO 30M 2007-07-12.jpg|thumb|right|A bottle of shower gel]] [[File:Shower Gel.jpg|thumb|Shower jellies]] '''Shower gel''' (also '''shower cream''' or '''body wash''') is a specialized [[liquid]] product used for cleaning the body during showers. Not to be confused with [[Liquid soap|liquid soaps]], shower gels, in fact, do not contain saponified oil. Instead, it uses synthetic detergents derived from either [[petroleum]] or plant sources.
Body washes and shower gels holds a lower [[pH]] value than the traditional soap, which is also known to feel less drying to the skin. In certain cases, [[sodium stearate]] is added to the chemical combination to create a solid version of the shower gel.
== History == Shower gel is a derivative invention of the liquid soap, which first appeared in the 1800s. In 1865, William Shepphard patented the formula behind the liquid soap<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rsc.org/learn-chemistry/resource/rdc00000822/on-this-day-aug-22-patent-for-liquid-soap?cmpid=CDC00000822|title=On This Day – August 22 : The first patent for liquid soap was issued to William Sheppard on this day in 1865- Learn Chemistry|website=www.rsc.org|language=en|access-date=2018-08-01}}</ref>, but the product gained eventual popularity with the rise of [[Palmolive soap]] in 1898, by B.J. Johnson.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thoughtco.com/history-of-soaps-and-detergents-4072778|title=The Cleanest Inventions: Soaps and Detergents|work=ThoughtCo|access-date=2018-08-01}}</ref>
Modern chemistry later{{when|date=September 2018}} enabled the creation of the shower gel, which specialized in cleaning the entire body during baths and showers.
== Properties ==
Shower gels are known to consist of the same basic ingredients as soap - water, [[betaine]]s, and [[sodium laureth sulfate]], or SLS. But the main difference between the two products lie in its [[surfactant]]s - compounds known to lower the surface tension between substances, which helps in the emulsification and the washing away of oily dirt. The surfactants of shower gels do not come from [[saponification]], that is by reacting a type of oil or fat with [[lye]]. Instead, it uses synthetic [[detergent]]s for surfactants derived from either plant-based sources or petroleum. This gives the product a lower pH value than soap<ref name="Pai 2016">{{cite web|url=https://www.glamour.com/story/bar-soap-benefits-versus-body-wash|title=Please Help Me Understand Why You Still Use Bar Soap|last=Pai|first=Deanna|date=November 23, 2016|website=Glamour|access-date=July 25, 2018}}</ref> and might also feel less drying to the skin.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/better/pop-culture/how-take-shower-according-dermatologists-ncna740526|title=Try these 11 expert tips for a better shower; your skin will thank you|work=NBC News|access-date=2018-08-01|language=en-US}}</ref> Some people have likened the effect to feeling less ''squeaky clean'', however. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wellandgood.com/good-looks/danger-of-being-squeaky-clean-after-shower/|title=Why you shouldn’t *actually* want to be squeaky-clean after a shower|website=Well+Good|language=en|access-date=2018-08-01}}</ref>
Surfactants can make up as much as 50 percent of the shower gel content, with the remaining proportion being made up of a combination of water and ingredients to thicken, preserve, emulsify, add fragrance, and color.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=How to Make Your Own Soap|last=Hornsey|first=Sally|publisher=Constable & Robinson|year=2014|isbn=9781908974235|location=London, England|pages=24, 198}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Cosmetic and Toiletry Formulations, Second Edition, Volume 2|last=Flick|first=Ernest|publisher=Noyes Publications|year=1992|isbn=0815513062|location=Park Ridge, New Jersey|pages=}}</ref> Multiple surfactants are often used to achieve desired product qualities. A primary surfactant can provide good foaming ability and cleaning effectiveness, while a secondary surfactant can add qualities of mildness to prevent irritation or over-drying of the skin. To prevent shower gel ingredients from separating, emulsifiers such as diethanolamine are added.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.chemservice.com/news/2014/08/examine-the-chemistry-of-body-wash/|title=EXAMINE THE CHEMISTRY OF BODY WASH|last=Boyd|first=Christopher|date=4 August 2014|website=www.chemservice.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-21}}</ref> Conditioning agents may also be added to moisturize the skin during and after product use.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://chemistscorner.com/cosmetic-formulations-body-wash/|title=Cosmetic Formulations – Body Wash – Chemists Corner|website=chemistscorner.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-21}}</ref> They are also available in different colours and scents.<ref name="Guarnieri 2014">{{cite web|url=https://fashionmagazine.com/beauty/how-we-bathe/|title=Bar soap vs. shower gel: A brief look at the history of how we bathe|last=Guarnieri|first=Anne-Marie|date=January 6, 2014|website=Fashion|access-date=July 25, 2018}}</ref> Ingredients, like scent in the form of essential oils or fragrance oils<ref name=":0" /> and colorant in the form of water soluble dyes are common in shower gels.<ref name=":1" />
[[Microbead|Microbeads]] were commonly used in shower gels until recently. Microbeads are tiny spheres of plastic that were added to a variety of cosmetic products for their exfoliating qualities. They are too small to filter out of water systems and end up in waterways and oceans, potentially passing toxins to animal life and humans. Following the legislative actions of other countries, the United States passed the [[Microbead-Free Waters Act 2015|Microbead-Free Waters Act]] in 2015, which bans microbeads in the U.S. incrementally starting in 2017, with full implementation set for 2019.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bailey Bischoff Staff|first=|date=18 April 2018|title=How the world made macro strides in curbing microbeads.|url=|journal=Christian Science Monitor|volume=|pages=|via=MAS Ultra - School Edition}}</ref>
Shower gels for men may contain the ingredient [[menthol]], which gives a cooling and stimulating sensation on the skin, and some men's shower gels are also designed specifically for use on hair and body. Shower gels contain milder surfactant bases than shampoos, and some also contain gentle conditioning agents in the formula. This means that shower gels can also double as an effective and perfectly acceptable substitute to shampoo,{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}} even if they are not labelled as a hair and body wash. Washing hair with shower gel should give approximately the same result as using a moisturising shampoo.{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}}
== Marketing ==
Like shampoo and bubble bath products, many are marketed directly towards children. These often feature scents intended to appeal to children, such as fruit scents, or cookies or cotton candy scents. Many bottles feature popular characters from children's television or movies. As with men's body wash, they often are specifically designed to be used also as a shampoo and conditioner. They also often contain gentle ingredients designed for young skin.

Body Wash | website=Ask Men | date=April 25, 2017 | url=https://www.askmen.com/grooming/appearance/bar-soap-vs-body-wash.html | access-date=July 25, 2018}} * {{cite web | last=Derbyshire | first=David | title=Shower gel better than soap? It just won't wash | website=Daily Mail Online | date=October 12, 2011 | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2048496/Shower-gel-better-soap-It-just-wont-wash.html | access-date=July 25, 2018}}

revision.comment: factually incorrect - SiPM is not sort of APD, but rather evolution of SPAD
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=November 2015}}
[[Image:SiPM IRST.JPG|300px|thumb|One of the first SiPM produced by FBK research center (formerly IRST) located in Trento, Italy. See http://www.fbk.eu.]] '''Silicon photomultipliers''', often called "'''SiPM'''" in the literature, are [[Solid-state electronics|solid-state]] single-[[photon]]-sensitive devices based on [[Single-photon avalanche diode]] (SPAD) implemented on common silicon substrate.<ref>[http://www.in2p3.fr/actions/formation/microelectronique13/Cours_SiPM_Dinu_preliminary.pdf Détecteurs SiPM]</ref><ref>[https://indico.cern.ch/event/117424/contributions/1329247/attachments/56777/81753/STMicroelectronics_SIPM_CERN_2011-02-17.pdf Silicon Photom ultiplier Technology at STMicroelectronics From SPAD to SiPM]</ref> The dimension of each single SPAD can vary from 10 to 100 micrometres, and their density can be up to 10000 per square millimeter. Every SPAD in SiPM operates in [[Single-photon avalanche diode|Geiger mode]] and is coupled with the others by a metal or [[polysilicon]] quenching resistor. Although the device works in digital/switching mode, most of SiPM are an [[analog device]] because all the microcells are read in parallel, making it possible to generate signals within a dynamic range from a single [[photon]] to 1000 [[photon]]s for a device with just a square-millimeter area. More advanced readout schemes are utilized for the [[lidar]] applications.<ref>[http://www.st.com/content/ccc/resource/technical/document/datasheet/group3/7d/85/c8/95/fb/3b/4e/2d/DM00452094/files/DM00452094.pdf/jcr:content/translations/en.DM00452094.pdf A new generation, long distance ranging Time-of-Flight sensor based on ST’s FlightSense™ technology]</ref> The supply voltage (''V''<sub>b</sub>) depends on APD technology used and typically varies between 20 V and 100 V, thus being from 15 to 75 times lower than the voltage required for a traditional [[Photomultiplier|photomultiplier tubes]] (PMTs) operation.
Typical specifications for a SiPM: # Photo detection efficiency (PDE) ranges from 20 to 50%, depending on device and wavelength, being similar to a traditional [[Photomultiplier tube|PMT]]. # Gain (''G'') is also similar to a [[Photomultiplier tube|PMT]], being about 10<sup>6</sup>. # ''G'' vs. ''V''<sub>b</sub> dependence is linear, does not follow a [[power law]] like in the case of [[Photomultiplier tube|PMT]]s. # Timing jitter is optimized to have a photon arrival time resolution of about 100-300 ps. # Signal decay time is inversely proportional to square root of photoelectrons number within an excitation event. # The signal parameters are practically independent of external magnetic fields, in contrast to vacuum [[Photomultiplier tube|PMT]]s. # Aftepulsing probability (3-30%) define probability of spurious second pulse on single photon arrival. # Dark count density is frequency of pulses in absence of illumination (10<sup>5</sup>-10<sup>6</sup> pulses/s/mm<sup>2</sup>) # Small dimensions permit extremely compact, light and robust mechanical design.
SiPM for medical imaging are attractive candidates for the replacement of the conventional [[Photomultiplier tube|PMT]] in [[Positron emission tomography|PET]] and [[SPECT]] imaging, since they provide high gain with low voltage and fast response, they are very compact and compatible with magnetic resonance setups. Nevertheless, there are still several challenges, for example, SiPM requires optimization for larger matrices, signal amplification and digitization.
==References== {{reflist}} * [https://www.ketek.net/sipm/technology/ Technology of KETEK-SiPM] * [http://www.sensl.com/downloads/ds/TN%20-%20Intro%20to%20SPM%20Tech.pdf SensL Technical Note] * [http://www.hamamatsu.com/jp/en/community/optical_sensors/articles/technical_note_mppc_sipm/index.html Hamamatsu Technical Note]

{{Infobox company | name = Sitronics | logo = Sitronics logo.png | type = [[Joint-stock company]] | industry = | fate = | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = 1997 | founder = <!-- or: | founders = --> | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location_city = [[Moscow]] | hq_location_country = Russia | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = | products = | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | num_employees = | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | parent = [[Sistema]] | website = {{URL|sitronics.ru}} }} '''Sitronics''' ({{lang-ru|Ситро́никс}}) is a microelectronics company based in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]] and controlled by [[Sistema]] holding, that also manufactures mobile phones. Its main assets are the [[Fabs|electronics fabs]], research and development facilities [[Mikron Group|NIIME and Mikron]] in [[Zelenograd]], and other facilities elsewhere in [[Eastern Europe]].
Despite losses in 2007, the company is planning to remain a part of Sistema and to expand its product portfolio,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/sitronics-idUSL1238527320080212|title=Russia's Sitronics sets new product strategy|date=12 February 2008|publisher=|via=Reuters}}</ref> bidding for large telecommunications contracts such as a $1 billion deal to build a network in Saudi Arabia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aUa6Nxjbf9E8&refer=india|title=Sistema Plans to Borrow $10 Billion to Expand Network (Update1)|website=Bloomberg.com|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020165111/http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aUa6Nxjbf9E8&refer=india|archivedate=2012-10-20|df=}}</ref>
==History== Sitronics was founded in 1997 in [[Zelenograd]] and was initially named "Scientific Center". In January 2005 its headquarters was moved to [[Moscow]] and in November 2005 the company got its current name. On February 7, 2007 the company placed an [[Initial Public Offering|IPO]] on the [[London Stock Exchange]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB120096958852205497|title=Russia Has a Tough Sell|first1=Andrew|last1=Langley|first2=Leos|last2=Rousek|date=22 January 2008|publisher=|via=www.wsj.com}}</ref> Through a series of acquisitions it has become a leading Russian microelectronics company with revenues exceeding $1 billion in the first 9 months of 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sitronics.com/site/10/article/94/|title=Sitronics :: Press Releases|date=5 June 2008|publisher=|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080605072808/http://www.sitronics.com/site/10/article/94/|archivedate=5 June 2008|df=}}</ref> The company delisted from the London Stock Exchange in 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sistema Gets Full Control of Sitronics|url=https://themoscowtimes.com/articles/sistema-gets-full-control-of-sitronics-17240|accessdate=27 August 2017|publisher=Moscow Times|language=en}}</ref>
==Telecommunications== The company will produce nano-SIM cards on orders from one of Russia’s big three mobile phone operators to be used in new Apple iPhones. The first batch will comprise about 50,000 cards that will be used in iPhone 5 gadgets.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.rian.ru/business/20120821/175349639.html |title=Russia’s ‘Big Three’ Mobile Firm Orders Sitronics NanoSIMs for iPhone 5}}</ref>
Sitronics also makes an array of mobile phones.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mob.org/phone/sitronics/|title=Sitronics phones and smartphones}}</ref>

{{pp-pc1|expiry=October 21, 2019}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox software | name = Snapchat | logo = Snapchat logo.svg | logo size = 100 | collapsible = yes | author = {{flatlist| * [[Evan Spiegel]] * [[Bobby Murphy (businessman)|Bobby Murphy]] * [[Snap Inc.#Controversy|Reggie Brown]] }} | developer = [[Snap Inc.]] | released = {{Start date and age|2011|9}} | ver layout = stacked | operating system = [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[iOS]] | size = 65.3 [[Megabyte|MB]] (Android)
243.9 MB (iOS) | language = English, Arabic, Danish, Dutch, Finnish, French, German, Greek, Indonesian, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Norwegian Bokmål, Polish, Portuguese, Romanian, Russian, Simplified Chinese, Spanish, Swedish, Traditional Chinese, Turkish, Filipino | language count = 22 | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Photo sharing]] * [[Instant messaging]] * [[Videotelephony|Video chat]] * [[Multimedia]] }} | license = [[Proprietary software]] | alexa = {{DecreasePositive}} 4,115 ({{asof|2018|10|01}}){{cite web |title=Snapchat.com Traffic, Demographics and Competitors - Alexa |url=https://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/snapchat.com |website=www.alexa.com |accessdate=1 October 2018 |language=en}} | website = {{URL|https://www.snapchat.com/}} }} '''Snapchat''' is a [[multimedia]] [[messaging app]] used globally, created by [[Evan Spiegel]], [[Bobby Murphy (businessman)|Bobby Murphy]], and Reggie Brown, former students at [[Stanford University]], and developed by [[Snap Inc.]], originally Snapchat Inc. One of the principal features of Snapchat is that pictures and messages are usually only available for a short time before they become inaccessible to users. The app has evolved from originally focusing on person-to-person photo sharing to presently featuring users' "Stories" of 24 hours of chronological content, along with "Discover", letting brands show ad-supported short-form content. Snapchat has become notable for representing a new, mobile-first direction for [[social media]], and places significant emphasis on users interacting with virtual stickers and [[augmented reality]] objects. As of February 2018, Snapchat has 187 million daily active users.{{cite web|url=https://www.statista.com/statistics/545967/snapchat-app-dau/|title=Snapchat daily active users 2017 - Statistic|website=Statista}}{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/02/06/snap-inc-earnings-q4-2017/|title=Snap shares skyrocket on first earnings beat with revived user growth – TechCrunch|website=techcrunch.com|language=en-US|access-date=April 11, 2018}} == History == {{For timeline|Timeline of Snapchat}} === Prototype === According to documents and [[Deposition (law)|deposition]] statements, Reggie Brown brought the idea for a disappearing pictures application to [[Evan Spiegel]] because Spiegel had prior business experience. Brown and Spiegel then pulled in [[Bobby Murphy (businessman)|Bobby Murphy]], who had experience [[Computer program|coding]]. The three worked closely together for several months and launched Snapchat as "Picaboo" on the [[iOS]] operating system on July 8, 2011.{{cite web |first=Jim |last=Edwards |title=The alleged betrayal described in these photos, texts, and emails cost Snapchat $158 million |url=http://nordic.businessinsider.com/snapchat-founders-lawsuit-internal-photos-texts-emails-2017-2 |website=[[Business Insider]] |publisher=[[Axel Springer SE]] |date=February 3, 2017 |accessdate=April 27, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Billy |last=Gallagher |title=Snapchat’s Spiegel Admits Brown "Came Up With The Idea For Disappearing Picture Messages" In New Court Documents |url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/07/01/new-snapchat-docs/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=July 1, 2013 |accessdate=April 27, 2017}} Reggie Brown was ousted from the company months after it was launched.{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-live-updates-snap-ipo-what-happened-to-ousted-snapchat-1488401913-htmlstory.html#|title=What happened to ousted Snapchat founder Reggie Brown? No, really, we don't know|last=Masunaga|first=Samantha|website=latimes.com|access-date=2018-08-24}} The app was relaunched as Snapchat in September 2011, and the team focused on usability and technical aspects, rather than branding efforts. One exception was the decision to keep a mascot designed by Brown, "Ghostface Chillah", named after [[Ghostface Killah]] of the hip-hop group [[Wu-Tang Clan]]. On May 8, 2012, Reggie Brown sent an email to Evan Spiegel during their senior year at Stanford in which he offered to re-negotiate his equitable share regarding ownership of the company. Lawyers for Snapchat responded by insisting that he had never had any creative connection to the product. The attorneys also accused Brown of committing [[fraud]] against Spiegel and Murphy by falsely claiming to be a product inventor. On behalf of their clients, the law firm concluded that [[Snap Inc.#Controversy|Reggie Brown]] had made no contributions of value or worth, and was therefore entitled to a share of nothing.Original document, [http://www.documentcloud.org/documents/725391-151160912-snapchat-reggie-brown-declaration.html "151160912 Snapchat Reggie Brown Declaration"], ''Sam Biddle Documentcloud'', July 10, 2013. Retrieved March 27, 2016.{{cite web |first=Billy |last=Gallagher |title=Evan Spiegel And Bobby Murphy Say Alleged Snapchat Co-Founder Never Had Equity |url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/07/31/spiegel-murphy-say-alleged-snapchat-co-founder-never-had-equity/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=July 31, 2013 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} In September 2014, Brown settled with Spiegel and Murphy for $157.5 million{{cite web |first=Melissa |last=Etehad |title=Two of these guys run Snap now. The third sued them. |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-live-updates-snap-ipo-the-dispute-with-snapchat-s-founders-1486156050-htmlstory.html |website=[[Los Angeles Times]] |publisher=[[Tronc]] |date=February 3, 2017 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} and was credited as one of the original authors of Snapchat.{{cite web |first=Felix |last=Gillette |title=Snapchat Reaches Settlement With Its Disappearing Co-Founder |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-09-09/snapchat-settles-reggie-brown-suit-credits-him-with-original-idea |website=[[Bloomberg L.P.]] |date=September 10, 2014 |accessdate=April 27, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Alyson |last=Shontell |title=Snapchat Settles Lawsuit Filed By Ousted Co-Founder And Fraternity Brother, Reggie Brown |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/snapchat-settles-the-lawsuit-with-the-ousted-co-founder-and-fraternity-brother-reggie-brown-2014-9 |website=[[Business Insider]] |publisher=[[Axel Springer SE]] |date=September 9, 2014 |accessdate=April 27, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Jordan |last=Crook |title=Snapchat Finally Settles Lawsuit With Ousted Co-Founder Reggie Brown |url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/09/09/snapchat-finally-settles-lawsuit-with-ousted-co-founder-reggie-brown/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=September 9, 2014 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} In their first [[blog]] post, dated May 9, 2012, [[CEO]] Evan Spiegel described the company's mission: "Snapchat isn’t about capturing the traditional [[Kodak]] moment. It’s about communicating with the full range of human emotion — not just what appears to be pretty or perfect."{{cite web |first=Evan |last=Spiegel |authorlink=Evan Spiegel |title=Let's chat. |url=https://www.snap.com/en-US/news/page/7/ |website=Snap News |publisher=[[Snap Inc.]] |date=May 9, 2012 |accessdate=April 27, 2017}} He presented Snapchat as the solution to stresses caused by the longevity of personal information on social media, evidenced by "emergency detagging of [[Facebook]] photos before job interviews and [[photo manipulation|photoshopping]] blemishes out of candid shots before they hit the internet". === Growth === [[File:Snapchat's global reach in 2014.png|left|thumb|World map indicating Snapchat's core users by country in 2014. Map based on data from a report from [[Business Insider]] Intelligence.{{cite web |first=Marcelo |last=Ballve |title=Snapchat Has Gone Global — These Are The Countries Where It Has Reached The Top Of The App Charts |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/snapchat-has-gone-global-these-are-the-countries-where-snapchat-has-conquered-the-app-charts-2014-7 |website=[[Business Insider]] |publisher=[[Axel Springer SE]] |date=July 30, 2014 |accessdate=May 9, 2017}}]] As of May 2012, 25 Snapchat images were being sent per second and, as of November 2012, users had shared over one billion photos on the Snapchat iOS app, with 20 million photos being shared per day.{{cite news|title=The app with self-destructing messages launches on Android|url=http://upstart.bizjournals.com/news/technology/2012/10/29/snapchat-launches-on-android.html|accessdate=December 22, 2012|newspaper=Upstart Business Journal|date=October 27, 2012|author=del Castillo, Michael }} That same month, Spiegel cited problems with user base [[scalability]] as the reason why Snapchat was experiencing some difficulties delivering its images, known as "snaps", in [[Real-time data|real time]]. Snapchat was released as an [[Android (operating system)|Android]] app on October 29, 2012. In June 2013, Snapchat version 5.0, dubbed "[[Banquo]]", was released for iOS. The updated version introduced several speed and design enhancements, including swipe navigation, double-tap to reply, an improved friend finder, and in-app profiles.{{cite web|title=Snapchat Update Adds Quicker, Flashier Features|url=http://mashable.com/2013/06/06/snapchat-update/|work=Mashable|publisher=Mashable|accessdate=August 9, 2013|author=Fitz-gerald, Sean |date=June 7, 2013}} The name is a reference to the ghostly hero from Shakespeare's [[Macbeth]], a character in the play who is ultimately seen to be victorious over evil.{{cite web |first=Jordan |last=Crook |title=Snapchat Launches v5.0 With Revamped UI, Swipe Navigation, And In-App Profiles |url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/06/05/snapchat-launches-v5-0-banquo-with-revamped-ui-address-book-friend-finder-and-in-app-profiles/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=June 5, 2013 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} Also in June 2013, Snapchat introduced Snapkidz for users under 13 years of age. Snapkidz was part of the original Snapchat application and was activated when the user provided a date of birth to verify his/her age. Snapkidz allowed children to take snaps and draw on them, but they could not send snaps to other users and could only save snaps locally on the device being used.{{cite web |first=Larry |last=Magid |title=Snapchat Creates SnapKidz -- A Sandbox For Kids Under 13 |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/larrymagid/2013/06/23/snapchat-creates-snapkidz-a-sandbox-for-kids-under-13/ |website=[[Forbes]] |date=June 23, 2013 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} According to Snapchat's published statistics, as of May 2015, the app's users were sending 2 billion videos per day, reaching 6 billion by November.{{cite web |first=Lucas |last=Matney |title=Snapchat Reaches 6 Billion Daily Videos Views, Tripling From 2 Billion In May |url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/11/09/snapchat-reaches-6-billion-daily-videos-views-tripling-from-2-billion-in-may/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=November 9, 2015 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} By 2016, Snapchat had hit 10 billion daily video views.Kellen Beck,[http://mashable.com/2016/04/28/snapchat-video-views-billion/ "Snapchat users are watching 10 billion videos a day"], ''Mashable'', April 28, 2016. Retrieved May 4, 2016. In May 2016, Snapchat raised $1.81 billion in equity offering, suggesting strong investor interest in the company.Anya George,[https://finance.yahoo.com/news/snapchat-raises-1-81-billion-104713195.html "Snapchat raises $1.81 billion in new funding round"], ''Yahoo'', May 26, 2016. Retrieved May 31, 2016. By May 31, 2016, the app had almost 10 million daily active users in the United Kingdom.{{cite web |first=Rob |last=Price |title=Almost 10 million Brits use Snapchat every day |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/snapchat-has-nearly-10-million-daily-users-in-uk-dau-2016-5 |website=[[Business Insider]] |publisher=[[Axel Springer SE]] |date=May 31, 2016 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} In February 2017, Snapchat had 160 million daily active users,{{cite web |first1=Tom |last1=Dotan |first2=Amir |last2=Efrati |title=What Matters and What Doesn’t in Snap’s S-1 |url=https://www.theinformation.com/what-matters-and-what-doesnt-in-snaps-s-1 |website=The Information |date=February 1, 2017 |accessdate=April 29, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Josh |last=Constine |title=Snapchat reportedly hit 160M daily users and $400M revenue in 2016 |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/02/02/snap-ipo/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=February 2, 2017 |accessdate=April 29, 2017}} growing to 166 million in May.{{cite web |first=Josh |last=Constine |title=Snapchat hits 166M daily users, disappointingly growing only slightly faster |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/05/10/snapchat-user-count/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=May 10, 2017 |accessdate=May 10, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Harrison |last=Weber |title=Snapchat now has 166 million users, 34 million fewer than Instagram Stories |url=https://venturebeat.com/2017/05/10/snapchat-now-has-166-million-users-34-million-fewer-than-instagram-stories/ |website=[[VentureBeat]] |date=May 10, 2017 |accessdate=May 10, 2017}} [[File:Snapchat Spectacles.jpg|thumb|Snapchat Spectacles Vending Machine at SXSW 2017, Austin, Texas]] In September 2016, Snapchat Inc. was renamed [[Snap Inc.]] to coincide with the introduction of the company's first [[computer hardware|hardware]] product, [[Spectacles (product)|Spectacles]]— [[smartglasses]] with a built-in camera that can record 10 seconds of video at a time.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-37460682 |title=Snapchat announces Sunglasses with built-in camera |last=Lee |first=Dave |date=September 24, 2016 |access-date=September 26, 2016}} On February 20, 2017, Spectacles became available for purchase online.{{cite web |first=Lexy |last=Savvides |title=Finally! Spectacles are available online |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/finally-snap-snapchat-spectacles-are-sold-online/ |website=[[CNET]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |date=February 20, 2017 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} == Features == === Core functionality === Snapchat is primarily used for creating multimedia messages referred to as "snaps"; snaps can consist of a photo or a short video, and can be edited to include filters and effects, text captions, and drawings.{{cite web|title=7 Snapchat tips and tricks you probably had no clue about|url=http://www.pocket-lint.com/news/132491-7-snapchat-tips-and-tricks-you-probably-had-no-clue-about|website=Pocket-lint|accessdate=December 19, 2015}}{{cite web|title=Snapchat Hands-on: Send Photos Set to Self-Destruct|url=http://blog.laptopmag.com/hands-on-with-snapchat-send-photos-set-to-self-destruct|work=Laptop|publisher=TechMedia Network|accessdate=September 15, 2013|author=Alba, Davey |date=May 16, 2012}} Snaps can be directed privately to selected contacts, or to a semi-public "Story". The ability to send video snaps was added as a feature option in December 2012. By holding down on the photo button while inside the app, a video of up to ten seconds in length can be captured. After a single viewing, the video disappears by default. Spiegel explained that this process allowed the video data to be compressed into the size of a photo.{{cite web |first=J.J. |last=Colao |title=Snapchat Adds Video, Now Seeing 50 Million Photos A Day |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jjcolao/2012/12/14/snapchat-adds-video-now-seeing-50-million-photos-a-day/ |website=[[Forbes]] |date=December 14, 2012 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} On May 1, 2014, the ability to communicate via [[Videoconferencing|video chat]] was added. Direct messaging features were also included in the update, allowing users to send [[ephemerality|ephemeral]] text messages to friends and family while saving any needed information by clicking on it.{{cite web |first=Romain |last=Dillet |title=Snapchat Adds Ephemeral Text Chat And Video Calls |url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/05/01/snapchat-adds-text-chat-and-video-calls/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=May 1, 2014 |accessdate=April 27, 2017}} Private message photo snaps can be viewed for a user-specified length of time (1 to 10 seconds as determined by the sender) before they become inaccessible. Users were previously required to hold down on the screen in order to view a snap; this behavior was removed in July 2015{{cite web |first=Sam |last=Sheffer |title=Snapchat is changing the way you watch snaps and add friends |url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/7/1/8861131/snapchat-update-2015-tap-to-play-story |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=July 1, 2015 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} The requirement to hold on the screen was intended to frustrate the ability to take [[screenshot]]s of snaps; the Snapchat app does not prevent screenshots from being taken but can notify the sender if it detects that it has been saved. However, these notifications can be bypassed through either unauthorized modifications to the app or by obtaining the image through external means.{{cite web |first=J.J. |last=Colao |title=Snapchat: The Biggest No-Revenue Mobile App Since Instagram |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jjcolao/2012/11/27/snapchat-the-biggest-no-revenue-mobile-app-since-instagram/ |website=[[Forbes]] |date=November 27, 2012 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Billy |last=Gallagher |title=You Know What’s Cool? A Billion Snapchats: App Sees Over 20 Million Photos Shared Per Day, Releases On Android |url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/10/29/billion-snapchats/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=October 29, 2012 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}}{{cite news|title=Fast-Growing Photo-Messaging App Snapchat Launches on Android|url=http://allthingsd.com/20121029/fast-growing-photo-messaging-app-snapchat-launches-on-android/|accessdate=December 22, 2012|newspaper=All Things D|date=October 29, 2012|author=Gannes, Liz }} One snap per day can be replayed for free. In September 2015, Snapchat introduced the option to purchase additional replays through [[Microtransaction|in-app purchases]].{{cite web |first=Lauren |last=Hockenson |title=Snapchat Replay? You can now pay Snapchat to replay snaps! |url=https://thenextweb.com/apps/2015/09/15/snapchats-latest-update-brings-selfie-lenses-paid-replays/ |website=The Next Web |date=September 15, 2015 |accessdate=May 4, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Brian |last=Barrett |title=Snapchat Now Charges if You Want to Replay Snaps |url=https://www.wired.com/2015/09/snapchat-replay-paid |website=[[Wired (website)|Wired]] |publisher=[[Condé Nast]] |date=September 15, 2015 |accessdate=May 4, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Sean |last=O'Kane |title=Snapchat now lets you pay to replay snaps |url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/9/15/9330955/snapchat-replay-snaps-paid-in-app |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=September 15, 2015 |accessdate=May 4, 2017}} The ability to purchase extra replays was removed in April 2016.{{cite web |first=Alex |last=Heath |title=Snapchat quietly made a big change to the way messages expire |url=https://www.businessinsider.com.au/snapchat-lets-you-reply-to-every-snap-once-2016-4 |website=[[Business Insider]] |publisher=[[Axel Springer SE]] |date=April 22, 2016 |accessdate=May 4, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Jordan |last=Valinsky |title=Snapchat quietly kills in-app purchase option |url=https://digiday.com/media/snapchat-shelves-snap-replays/ |website=''[[Digiday]]'' |date=April 22, 2016 |accessdate=May 4, 2017}} Friends can be added via usernames and phone contacts, using customizable "[[Aztec Code|Snapcodes]]", or through the "Add Nearby" function, which scans for users near their location who are also in the Add Nearby menu.{{cite web|title=What marketers should know about Snapchat|url=http://www.brandrepublic.com/news/1186152/sexting-branding-marketers-know-snapchat-nickykc/|work=Brand Republic|publisher=[[Haymarket Media Group]]|accessdate=July 21, 2013|author=Kemp, Nicola |date=June 13, 2013}} Spiegel explained that Snapchat is intended to counteract the trend of users being compelled to manage an idealized [[online identity]] of themselves, which he says has "taken all of the fun out of communicating". In November 2014, Snapchat introduced "Snapcash", a feature that lets users send and receive money to each other through private messaging. The payments system is powered by [[Square, Inc.|Square]].{{cite web |first=Kurt |last=Wagner |title=Snapchat to Let You Send Money to Friends, Thanks to Square |url=https://www.recode.net/2014/11/17/11632930/snapchat-to-let-you-send-money-to-friends-thanks-to-square |website=[[Recode]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=November 17, 2014 |accessdate=April 27, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Josh |last=Constine |title=Snapchat Now Lets You Send Money To Friends Through Snapcash Deal With Square Cash |url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/11/17/snapcash/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=November 17, 2014 |accessdate=April 27, 2017}} In July 2016, Snapchat introduced a new, optional feature known as "Memories". Memories allows snaps and story posts to be saved into a private storage area, where they can be viewed alongside other photos stored on the device, as well as edited and published as snaps, story posts, or messages. When shared to a user's current story, the memory would have a white frame and timestamp to indicate its age. Content in the Memories storage area can be searched by date or using a local [[object recognition]] system. Snaps accessible within Memories can additionally be placed into a "My Eyes Only" area that is locked with a PIN. Snapchat has stated that the Memories feature was inspired by the practice of manually scrolling through photos on a phone to show them to others.{{cite web |first=Casey |last=Newton |title=Snapchat introduces Memories: a searchable, shareable archive of your snaps |url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/7/6/12102294/snapchat-memories-private-snap-archive |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=July 6, 2016 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} In April 2017, the white border around old memories was removed. While originally intended to let viewers know the material was old, ''[[TechCrunch]]'' wrote that the indicator "ended up annoying users who didn’t want their snaps altered, sometimes to the point where they would decide not to share the old content at all".{{cite web |first=Fitz |last=Tepper |title=Snapchat will no longer show a white border around old Memories |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/04/27/snapchat-will-no-longer-show-a-white-border-around-old-memories/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=April 27, 2017 |accessdate=April 28, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Zack |last=Gilbert |title=Snapchat stops putting a white border around old Memories |url=http://mobilesyrup.com/2017/04/27/snapchat-stops-putting-white-border-around-old-memories/ |website=MobileSyrup |date=April 27, 2017 |accessdate=April 28, 2017}} In May 2017, an update made it possible to send snaps with unlimited viewing time, dropping the previous ten-second maximum duration, with the content disappearing after being deliberately closed by the recipient. New creative tools, namely the ability to draw with an emoji, videos that play in a loop, and an eraser that lets users remove objects in a photo with the app filling in the space with the background, were also released.{{cite web |first=Casey |last=Newton |title=Snapchat adds new creative tools as its rivalry with Instagram intensifies |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/5/9/15592738/snapchat-limitless-snaps-looping-videos-magic-eraser-emoji-drawing |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=May 9, 2017 |accessdate=May 9, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Josh |last=Constine |title=Snapchat’s new eraser lets you photoshop stuff out of photos |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/05/09/snapchat-magic-eraser/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=May 9, 2017 |accessdate=May 9, 2017}} In June 2017, Snapchat started allowing users to add links to snaps, enabling them to direct viewers to specific websites; the feature was only available for brands previously. Additionally, the update added more creative tools: A "Backdrop" feature lets users cut out a specific object from their photo and apply colorful patterns to it in order to bring greater emphasis to that object, and "Voice Filters" enable users to remix the sounds of their voices in the snap. Voice Filters was previously available as part of the feature enabling augmented reality lenses, with the new update adding a dedicated speaker icon to remix the audio in any snap.{{cite web |first=Josh |last=Constine |title=Snapchat lets you add links, voice filters and backdrops to Snaps |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/07/05/snapchat-links-backdrops-voice-filters/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=July 5, 2017 |accessdate=July 7, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Shannon |last=Liao |title=Snapchat’s latest update lets you send links to friends |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/7/5/15923834/snapchat-link-sending-update-paperclip-voice-filters-backdrops |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=July 5, 2017 |accessdate=July 7, 2017}} ==== Filters, lenses, and stickers ==== Snaps can be personalized with various forms of visual effects and [[Sticker (messaging)|stickers]]. Geofilters are graphical overlays available if the user is [[Geo-fence|within a certain geographical location]], such as a city, event, or destination.{{cite web |first=Darrell |last=Etherington |title=Snapchat Adds Geofilters For Quick Image Location Tags, And A New Revenue Possibility |url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/07/15/snapchat-adds-geofilters-for-quick-image-location-tags-and-a-new-revenue-possibility/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=July 15, 2014 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} A similar feature known as Geostickers was launched in 10 major cities in 2016.{{cite web |first=John |last=Mannes |title=Snapchat lets the people have Geostickers |url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/08/02/snapchat-lets-the-people-have-geostickers/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=August 2, 2016 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} [[Bitstrips|Bitmoji]] are stickers featuring personalized cartoon [[avatar (computing)|avatars]], which can be used in snaps and messaging.{{cite web|title=Snapchat builds Bitmojis into app, confirms acquisition of Toronto startup|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/technology/tech-news/snapchat-builds-bitmojis-into-app-confirms-acquisition/article30975847/|website=The Globe and Mail|accessdate=March 24, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Here’s How You Can Use Bitmoji Inside Snapchat|url=http://fortune.com/2016/07/19/snapchat-bitmoji-integration/|website=Fortune|accessdate=March 24, 2017}} Bitmoji characters can also be used as World Lenses.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/9/14/16303504/snapchat-bitmoji-world-lenses-animation-gabsee|title=Snapchat's Bitmoji avatars are now three-dimensional and animated|work=The Verge|access-date=December 10, 2017}} The "Lens" feature, introduced in September 2015, allows users to add real-time effects into their snaps by using [[face detection]] technology. This is activated by long-pressing on a face within the viewfinder.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailydot.com/technology/new-snapchat-selfie-lenses/|title=How to use Snapchat's new selfie Lenses|website=The Daily Dot|access-date=March 12, 2016}} In April 2017, Snapchat extended this feature into "World Lenses", which use [[augmented reality]] technology to integrate [[3D computer graphics|3D rendered]] elements (such as objects and animated characters) into scenes; these elements are placed and anchored in [[3D space]].{{cite web |first=Casey |last=Newton |title=Snapchat adds world lenses to further its push into augmented reality |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/4/18/15333130/snapchat-world-lenses-something-new-for-facebook-to-copy |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=April 18, 2017 |accessdate=December 13, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Darrell |last=Etherington |title=Snapchat introduces World Lenses – live filters for just about anything |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/04/18/snapchat-introduces-world-lenses-live-filters-for-just-about-anything/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[Oath Inc.]] |date=April 18, 2017 |accessdate=April 18, 2017}} On October 26, 2018 at [[TwitchCon]], Snap launched the Snap Camera desktop application for macOS and Windows PCs, which enables use of Snapchat lenses in video chat and live streaming services such as [[Skype]], [[Twitch.tv|Twitch]], [[YouTube]], and [[Zoom Video Communications|Zoom]]. Snapchat also launched integration with Twitch, including an in-stream [[Software widget|widget]] for Snapcodes, the ability to offer lenses to stream viewers and as an incentive to channel subscribers. Several video game-themed lenses were also launched at this time, including ones themed around ''[[League of Legends]]'', ''[[Overwatch (video game)|Overwatch]]'', and ''[[PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds]]''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2018/10/26/twitch-snap-camera-snapchat-augmented-reality-filters/|title=Twitch streamers are getting Snap's AR selfie filters|work=Engadget|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/10/26/18026688/snap-camera-snapchat-lenses-twitch-youtube-skype|title=Snapchat brings its camera to the desktop to add filters to your streaming videos|work=The Verge|access-date=2018-11-06}} ==== Friend Emojis ==== {| class="wikitable" |+As incentive to send content regularly, emoji icons will appear next to the names of contacts that the user frequently interacts with.{{cite web |title=Friend Emojis |url=https://support.snapchat.com/en-US/a/friend-emojis |website=Snapchat Support |publisher=Snapchat |accessdate=May 9, 2017}} |- ! Emoji !! Friend Emoji Name !! Snapchat Meaning |- | 💕 || Super BFF || Appears next to the user's number 1 Best Friend when they are also their number 1 Best Friend for two months in a row. |- | ❤️ || BFF ||Appears next to the user's number 1 Best Friend when they are also their number 1 Best Friend for two weeks in a row. |- | 💛 || Besties || Appears next to the user's number 1 Best Friend when they are also their number 1 Best Friend. |- | 😊 || BFs || Appears next to one of the user's Best Friends |- | 😏 || Their BF, but... || Appears next to someone when the user is one of their Best Friends, but they are not one of the user's. |- | 😬 || Mutual Besties ||Appears next to someone when the user's number 1 Best Friend is also their number 1 Best Friend. |- | 😎 || Mutual BFs || Appears next to someone whom the user shares a best friend with. |- | 🔥 || Snapstreak || Appears next to the number of days that the user and a friend have Snapped each other. If the user and their friend do not both send a Snap within 24 hours, they will lose their Snapstreak. |- |✨ |Group Chat |Appears next to all of the user's group chats. |- | ⌛️ || Hourglass || Appears next to someone’s name if the user's Snapstreak is going to end soon. |- | 🎂 || Birthday Cake || Appears next to someone when it is their birthday |} === Stories and Discover === In October 2013, Snapchat introduced the "My Story" feature, which allows users to compile snaps into chronological storylines, accessible to all of their friends.{{cite web |first=Darrell |last=Etherington |title=Snapchat Gets Its Own Timeline With Snapchat Stories, 24-Hour Photo & Video Tales |url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/10/03/snapchat-gets-its-own-timeline-with-snapchat-stories-24-hour-photo-video-tales/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=October 3, 2013 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Ellis |last=Hamburger |title=Snapchat's next big thing: 'Stories' that don't just disappear |url=https://www.theverge.com/2013/10/3/4791934/snapchats-next-big-thing-stories-that-dont-just-disappear |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=October 3, 2013 |accessdate=April 27, 2017}} By June 2014, photo and video snaps presented to friends in the Stories functionality had surpassed person-to-person private snaps as the most frequently-used function of the service, with over one billion viewed per day — double the daily views tallied in April 2014.{{cite web |first=Ellis |last=Hamburger |title=Surprise: Snapchat's most popular feature isn't snaps anymore |url=https://www.theverge.com/2014/6/20/5827666/snapchat-stories-bigger-than-snaps-electric-daisy-carnival |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=June 20, 2014 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} In June 2014, the story feature was expanded to incorporate "Our Stories", which was then changed to "Live Stories" about a year later. The feature allows users on-location at specific events (such as [[music festival]]s or sporting events) to contribute snaps to a curated story advertised to all users, showcasing a single event from multiple perspectives and viewpoints. These curated snaps provided by the app's contributors and selected for the "Live" section could also be more localized, but Snapchat eventually scaled back the more personal imaging streams in order to emphasize public events.{{cite web |first=Carl |last=Franzen |title=Snapchat lets you watch and create group videos of live events with 'Our Story' |url=https://www.theverge.com/2014/8/29/6084221/snapchat-our-story-collective-snaps-from-live-events |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=August 29, 2014 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://blog.snapchat.com/post/89064817345/introducing-our-story|title=Snapchat – Introducing Our Story|work=Snapchat Blog|accessdate=May 16, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150522175232/http://blog.snapchat.com/post/89064817345/introducing-our-story|archivedate=May 22, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailydot.com/technology/snapchat-new-years-times-square/|title=Your Snapchat photo could wind up in Times Square tonight|work=The Daily Dot|accessdate=May 16, 2015}}{{cite web |first=Kurt |last=Wagner |title=Snapchat Is Making Some Pretty Serious Money From Live Stories |url=https://www.recode.net/2015/6/17/11563634/snapchats-making-some-pretty-serious-money-from-live-stories |website=[[Recode]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=June 17, 2015 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}}{{cite web |first=P. Claire |last=Dodson |title=Why Snapchat’s Live Stories Are The Most Powerful New Social Media |url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3052322/why-snapchats-live-stories-are-the-most-powerful-new-social-media |website=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]] |publisher=Mansueto Ventures |date=October 21, 2015 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Jacob |last=Kastrenakes |title=Snapchat ends local Stories to focus on live events |url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/9/7/12830618/snapchat-ends-local-stories-for-cities |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=September 7, 2016 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} An "Official Stories" designation was added in November 2015 to denote the public stories of notable figures and celebrities, similar to [[Twitter]]'s "Verified account" program.{{cite web |first=Casey |last=Newton |title=Snapchat rolls out 'official stories' to verify celebrity accounts |url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/11/13/9731440/snapchat-verified-accounts |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=November 13, 2015 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} In January 2015, Snapchat introduced "Discover", an area containing channels of ad-supported short-form content from major publishers, including [[BuzzFeed]], [[CNN]], [[ESPN]], [[Mashable]], [[People (magazine)|''People'']], [[Vice Media|Vice]] and [[Good Luck America|Snapchat]] itself among others.{{cite web |first=P. Claire |last=Dodson |title=A Millennial Reveals The Best, Worst, and Most Meh Snapchat Discover Channels |url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3052320/a-millennial-reveals-the-best-worst-and-most-meh-snapchat-discover-channels |website=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]] |publisher=Mansueto Ventures |date=October 22, 2015 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Amit |last=Chowdhry |title=Snapchat's New 'Discover' Feature Has Content From ESPN, CNN, Food Network And Others |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/amitchowdhry/2015/01/28/snapchat-discover/ |website=[[Forbes]] |date=January 28, 2015 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}}{{cite web |first1=Paresh |last1=Dave |first2=David |last2=Pierson |title=Cheap content, growing reach make Snapchat a fast-rising star |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-snapchat-new-business-20150417-story.html |website=[[Los Angeles Times]] |publisher=[[Tronc]] |date=April 16, 2015 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} To address data usage concerns related to these functions, a "Travel Mode" option was added in August 2015. When activated, the feature prevents the automatic downloading of snaps until they are explicitly requested by the user.{{cite web |first=Sam |last=Sheffer |title=Snapchat has a new feature to stop you from wasting data |url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/8/10/9126923/snapchat-data-usage-update-travel-mode-emoji-snapcode |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=August 10, 2015 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} In October 2016, the app was updated to replace its auto-advance functionality, which automatically moved users from one story to the next, with a "Story Playlist" feature, letting users select thumbnails of users in the list to play only selected stories.{{cite web |first=Josh |last=Constine |title=Snapchat launches post-roll ads, Story Playlist that loads favorites in bulk |url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/10/07/snapchat-story-playlist/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=October 7, 2016 |accessdate=July 7, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Marty |last=Swant |title=Snapchat Is Ditching Auto Advance Stories in Favor of Playlists |url=http://www.adweek.com/digital/snapchat-ditching-auto-advance-stories-favor-playlists-173964/ |website=[[Adweek]] |publisher=Beringer Capital |date=October 7, 2016 |accessdate=July 7, 2017}} In January 2017, Snapchat revamped its design, adding search functionality and a new global live "Our Story" feature, to which any user can contribute.{{cite web |first=Karissa |last=Bell |title=This is not a drill: Snapchat is about to get a major redesign |url=http://mashable.com/2017/01/12/snapchat-redesign-search-bar/ |website=[[Mashable]] |date=January 13, 2017 |accessdate=May 23, 2017}} In May 2017, Snapchat introduced "Custom Stories", letting users collaboratively make stories combining their captures.{{cite web |first=Casey |last=Newton |title=Snapchat introduces custom stories for capturing group moments with friends |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/5/23/15677712/snapchat-custom-stories-launch |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=May 23, 2017 |accessdate=May 23, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Darrell |last=Etherington |title=Snapchat now lets you create custom stories for groups of friends and family |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/05/23/snapchat-now-lets-you-create-custom-stories-for-groups-of-friends-and-family/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=May 23, 2017 |accessdate=May 23, 2017}} In June 2017, "Snap Map" was introduced, which allows users to optionally share their location with friends. A map display, accessible from the viewfinder, can be used to locate stories based on location data, supporting the use of Bitmoji as place markers. Entering a "Ghost Mode" hides the user from the map.{{cite web |first=Josh |last=Constine |title=Snapchat launches location-sharing feature Snap Map |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/06/21/snap-map/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=June 21, 2017 |accessdate=June 23, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Chris |last=Welch |title=Snapchat’s new Snap Map lets you share your location with friends |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/6/21/15846358/snapchat-snap-map-location-sharing-feature-announced |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=June 21, 2017 |accessdate=June 23, 2017}} The function is based on the app Zenly, which was acquired by Snap Inc. prior to its launch.{{cite web |first=Josh |last=Constine |title=Snapchat acquires social map app Zenly for $250M to $350M |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/06/21/snapchat-buys-zenly/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=June 21, 2017 |accessdate=June 23, 2017}} The map data is supplied from [[OpenStreetMap]] and [[Mapbox]], while satellite imagery comes from [[DigitalGlobe]].{{cite web |url=http://streetfightmag.com/2017/07/10/snapchat-expands-its-foray-into-local-with-snap-map/ |title=Snapchat Expands Its Foray Into Local with Snap Map |author=Rollison, Damian |work=Street Fight |date=July 10, 2017 |accessdate=September 22, 2017}} ==== Original video content ==== ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' reported in May 2017 that [[Snap Inc.]], the company developing Snapchat, had signed deals with [[NBCUniversal]], [[A&E Networks]], [[BBC]], [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], [[Metro–Goldwyn–Mayer]] and other content producers to develop original shows for viewing through Snapchat's "Stories" format. According to the report, Snap hopes to have several new shows available on a daily basis, with each show lasting between three and five minutes, and the company has sent out detailed reports to its partners on how to produce content for Snapchat.{{cite web |first=Shalini |last=Ramachandran |title=Media Companies Line Up to Make Shows for Snap TV |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/media-companies-line-up-to-make-shows-for-snap-tv-1493890205 |website=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |publisher=[[Dow Jones & Company]] |date=May 4, 2017 |accessdate=July 7, 2017}} {{subscription required}}{{cite web |first=Roger |last=Fingas |title=Snap signs major network deals for Snapchat TV shows |url=http://appleinsider.com/articles/17/05/04/snap-signs-major-network-deals-for-snapchat-tv-shows |website=AppleInsider |date=May 4, 2017 |accessdate=July 7, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Mitchel |last=Broussard |title=Snapchat Plans Original TV Shows Lasting 3-5 Minutes Each, Partners Include ABC, HGTV, and More |url=https://www.macrumors.com/2017/05/04/snapchat-original-tv-shows/ |website=[[MacRumors]] |date=May 4, 2017 |accessdate=July 7, 2017}} === Messaging === [[File:Snap on smartphone.jpg|thumb|right|Example Snapchat "snap" on a smartphone.]] In contrast to other messaging apps, Spiegel described Snapchat's messaging functions as being "conversational," rather than "transactional," as they sought to replicate the conversations he engaged in with friends. Spiegel stated that he did not experience conversational interactions while using the products of competitors like [[iMessage]]. Rather than a traditional online notification, a blue pulsing "Here" button is displayed within the sender's chat window if the recipient is currently viewing their own chat window. When this button is held down, a video chat function is immediately launched. By default, messages disappear after they are read, and a notification is sent to the recipient only when they start to type. Users can also use messages to reply to snaps that are part of a story.{{cite web |first=Casey |last=Newton |title=Snapchat introduces a 'lens store' to adorn your selfies with 99-cent filters |url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/11/13/9700312/snapchat-lens-store |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=November 13, 2015 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} The video chat feature uses technology from AddLive—a real-time communications provider that Snapchat acquired prior to the feature's launch.{{cite web |first=Ellis |last=Hamburger |title=Snapchat made a secret acquisition to power its new video chat |url=https://www.theverge.com/2014/5/2/5676196/snapchat-acquires-addlive-video-chat |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=May 2, 2014 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} In regards to the "Here" indicator, Spiegel explained that "the accepted notion of an online indicator that every chat service has is really a negative indicator. It means 'my friend is available and doesn't want to talk to you,' versus this idea in Snapchat where 'my friend is here and is giving you their full attention.'" Spiegel further claimed that the Here video function prevents the awkwardness that can arise from apps that use typing indicators because, with text communication, conversations lose their fluidity as each user tries to avoid typing at the same time.{{cite web |first=Ellis |last=Hamburger |title=Real talk: the new Snapchat brilliantly mixes video and texting |url=https://www.theverge.com/2014/5/1/5670260/real-talk-the-new-snapchat-makes-texting-fun-again-video-calls |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=May 1, 2014 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} On March 29, 2016, Snapchat launched a major revision of the messaging functionality known as "Chat 2.0", adding stickers, easier access to audio and video conferencing, the ability to leave audio or video "notes", and the ability to share recent camera photos. The implementation of these features are meant to allow users to easily shift between text, audio, and video chat as needed while retaining an equal level of functionality.{{cite web |first=Casey |last=Newton |title=Snapchat redesigns chat to add stickers, audio, and video notes |url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/3/29/11321150/snapchat-chat-redesign-stickers-audio-video-notes |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=March 29, 2016 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} In June 2018, Snapchat added the feature of deleting a sent message (including; audio, video, and text) before it is read.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/6/11/17449906/snapchat-delete-unopened-sent-messages-spectacles-amazon|title=Snapchat now lets you delete unopened sent messages|work=The Verge|access-date=June 12, 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://9to5mac.com/2018/06/11/snapchat-delete-sent-messages-spectacles-amazon/|title=Snapchat update lets you delete sent messages, Spectacles hit Amazon․com|date=June 11, 2018|work=9to5Mac|access-date=June 12, 2018|language=en-US}} A feature introduced in August 2018, allows users to send Musical GIFs, TuneMojis.{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/snapchat-musical-gifs-tunemoji-2018-8|title=You can now send musical GIFs to Snapchat|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-08-27}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/tech/snapchat-tunemoji-music-gifs-a3918361.html|title=You can now send music GIFs in Snapchat with TuneMoji|work=Evening Standard|access-date=2018-08-27|language=en-GB}} == Business and multimedia == ===Demographics=== From its earliest days, Snapchat's main demographic has consisted of [[millennials]].{{cite web|url=http://digiday.com/platforms/snapchat-pitching-brands-agencies/|title=Pitch deck: How Snapchat is selling itself to marketers – Digiday|work=[[Digiday]]|accessdate=May 16, 2015}} In 2014, researchers from the [[University of Washington]] and [[Seattle Pacific University]] designed a user survey to help understand how and why the application was being used. The researchers originally hypothesized that due to the ephemeral nature of Snapchat messages, its use would be predominantly for privacy-sensitive content including the much talked about potential use for sexual content and [[sexting]].{{cite web|last1=Roesner| first1=Franziska|first2=Brian T|last2=Gill|first3=Tadayoshi|last3=Kohno |title=Sex, Lies, or Kittens? Investigating the Use of Snapchat's Self-Destructing Messages|work=Financial Cryptography and Data Security Conference|date=2014|format=pdf|doi=10.1007/978-3-662-45472-5_5|url=https://homes.cs.washington.edu/~yoshi/papers/snapchat-FC2014.pdf}} However, it appears that Snapchat is used for a variety of creative purposes that are not necessarily privacy-related at all. In the study, only 1.6% of respondents reported using Snapchat primarily for sexting, although 14.2% admitted to having sent sexual content via Snapchat at some point. These findings suggest that users do not seem to utilize Snapchat for sensitive content. Rather, the primary use for Snapchat was found to be for comedic content such as "stupid faces" with 59.8% of respondents reporting this use most commonly. The researchers also determined how Snapchat users do not use the application and what types of content they are not willing to send. They found that the majority of users are not willing to send content classified as sexting (74.8% of respondents), photos of documents (85.0% of respondents), messages containing legally questionable content (86.6% of respondents), or content considered mean or insulting (93.7% of respondents). The study results also suggested that Snapchat's success is not due to its security properties, but because the users found the application to be fun. The researchers found that users seem to be well aware (79.4% of respondents) that recovering snaps is possible and a majority of users (52.8% of respondents) report that this does not affect their behavior and use of Snapchat. Many users (52.8% of respondents) were found to use an arbitrary timeout length on snaps regardless of the content type or recipient. The remaining respondents were found to adjust their snaps' timeout depending on the content or the recipient. Reasons for adjusting the time length of snaps included the level of trust and relationship with the recipient, the time needed to comprehend the snap, and avoiding [[screenshot]]s. ===Communication=== Snapchat has often been seen to represent a new direction in social media, with its users, particularly millennials, craving a more in-the-moment way of sharing and communicating via technology. With less emphasis on the accumulation of an ongoing status involving the presence of permanent material, Snapchat put focus on the ephemeral nature of fleeting encounters.Casey Johnston, [http://www.newyorker.com/tech/elements/snapchat-instagram-stories-and-the-internet-of-forgetting "Snachat, Instagram Stories, And The Internet Of Forgetting"], ''TheNewYorker'', August 5, 2016. Retrieved August 6, 2016. Building on this distinction by launching as a mobile-first company, Snapchat, in the midst of the app revolution and the growing presence of cellular communication, didn't have to make the transition to mobile in the way other competing social media networks had to do. Evan Spiegel himself described Snapchat as primarily a camera company.Ben Basche, [https://medium.freecodecamp.com/ghost-in-the-machine-snapchat-isnt-mobile-first-it-s-something-else-entirely-4f6c265152a2#.sqvrq1k2w "Ghost in the machine: Snapchat isn’t mobile-first — it’s something else entirely"], ''ibtimes.com'', July 28, 2016. Retrieved August 6, 2016.{{cite web |first=D.J. |last=Sherrets |title=According to its cofounder and CEO Snapchat is mainly "a camera company" |url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/04/30/according-to-its-cofounder-and-ceo-snapchat-is-mainly-a-camera-company/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=April 30, 2016 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} Spiegel also dismissed past comparisons to other social media networks such as Facebook and Twitter when he was asked if the 2016 presidential race was going to be remembered as the Snapchat election, although major candidates did occasionally use the app to reach voters.Kerry Flynn, [http://www.ibtimes.com/snapchat-ceo-evan-spiegel-stephen-colbert-despite-gop-embrace-2016-white-house-race-2122481 "Snapchat CEO Evan Spiegel To Stephen Colbert: Despite GOP Embrace, 2016 White House Race Definitely Not The Snapchat Election"], ''ibtimes.com'', October 1, 2015. Retrieved August 6, 2016. Nevertheless, the growing mobile app moved to offer distinct publication, media, and news content within its Discover channel, as well as with its overall style of presentation. With Snapchat, a clear and identifiable line was drawn between brand content and user-based messaging and sharing, once again distinguishing the popular app from other social media networks, which typically have blended and blurred their different varieties of content.Matthew Hussey, [https://thenextweb.com/insider/2016/05/04/story-snapchats-confusing-discover-feed/ "Snapchat’s Discover channel is quietly ruining the social network"], ''thenextweb.com'', May 8, 2016. Retrieved August 6, 2016. ===Monetization=== Snapchat's developing features embody a deliberate strategy of [[monetization]]. Snapchat announced its then-upcoming advertising efforts on October 17, 2014, when it acknowledged its need for a revenue stream.{{cite web |first=Garett |last=Sloane |title=Snapchat Says Ads Are Coming This Weekend: ‘We Need the Money’ |url=http://www.adweek.com/digital/snapchat-says-ads-are-coming-weekend-we-need-money-160857/ |website=[[Adweek]] |publisher=Beringer Capital |date=October 17, 2014 |accessdate=June 20, 2017}} The company stated that it wanted to evaluate "if we can deliver an experience that's fun and informative, the way ads used to be, before they got creepy and targeted."{{cite web |first=Stuart |last=Dredge |title=Snapchat messaging app gets its first ad... and it's very creepy |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/oct/20/snapchat-messaging-app-ad-creepy-ouija |website=[[The Guardian]] |publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]] |date=October 20, 2014 |accessdate=June 20, 2017}} Snapchat's first paid advertisement, in the form of a 20-second movie trailer for the horror film ''[[Ouija (2014 film)|Ouija]]'', was shown to users on October 19, 2014.{{cite web |first=Karissa |last=Bell |title=Snapchat Freaks Out Users With First Ad for 'Ouija' |url=http://mashable.com/2014/10/18/snapchat-ouija-ad/ |website=[[Mashable]] |date=October 19, 2014 |accessdate=June 20, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Marc |last=Graser |title=Snapchat Scares Up Advertising Business with ‘Ouija’ |url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/snapchat-scares-up-advertising-business-with-ouija-1201334130/ |website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]] |date=October 19, 2014 |accessdate=June 20, 2017}} In January 2015, Snapchat began making a shift from focusing on growth to monetization. The company launched its "Discover" feature, which allowed for paid advertising by presenting short-form content from publishers. Its initial launch partners included CNN, Comedy Central, ESPN and Food Network, among others.{{cite web |first=Alyson |last=Shontell |title=Advertisers are supposedly paying insanely high rates to get their ads on Snapchat |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/snapchat-discover-ad-rates-2015-3 |website=[[Business Insider]] |publisher=[[Axel Springer SE]] |date=March 12, 2015 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} In June 2015, Snapchat announced that it would allow advertisers to purchase sponsored geofilters for snaps; an early customer of the offering was [[McDonald's]], who paid for a branded geofilter covering its restaurant locations in the United States.{{cite web |first=Fitz |last=Tepper |title=Snapchat Turns Geofilters Into An Ad Unit |url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/06/16/snapchat-begins-charging-for-sponsored-geofilters/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=June 16, 2015 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} Snapchat made a push to earn ad revenue from its "Live Stories" feature in 2015, after initially launching the feature in 2014. Ad placements can be sold within a live story, or a story can be pitched by a sponsor. Live stories are estimated to reach an average of 20 million viewers in a 24-hour span. In September 2015, the service entered into a partnership with the [[National Football League]] to present live stories from selected games (including a Sunday game, and marquee games such as [[Monday Night Football]] and [[Thursday Night Football]]), with both parties contributing content and handling ad sales.{{cite web|url=https://www.recode.net/2015/9/17/11618660/snapchat-inks-nfl-deal-to-bring-football-into-its-live-stories|title=Snapchat Inks NFL Deal to Bring Football Into Its Live Stories|last=Wagner|first=Kurt|date=September 17, 2015|website=[[Recode]]|publisher=[[Vox Media]]|accessdate=April 10, 2017}} The 2015 Internet Trends Report by Mary Meeker highlighted the significant growth of [[vertical video]] viewing. Vertical video ads like Snapchat's are watched in their entirety nine times more than landscape video ads.{{Cite web|url=https://www.kleinerperkins.com/perspectives/2015-internet-trends|title=2015 Internet Trends|website=Kleiner Perkins|language=en|access-date=2018-08-24}} In April 2016, [[NBC Olympics]] announced that it had reached a deal with Snapchat to allow stories from the [[2016 Summer Olympics]] to be featured on Snapchat in the United States. The content would include a behind-the-scenes Discover channel curated by [[BuzzFeed]] (a company which [[NBCUniversal]] has funded), and stories featuring a combination of footage from NBC, athletes, and attendees. NBC will sell advertising and enter into revenue sharing agreements. This marked the first time NBC allowed Olympics footage to be featured on third-party property.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-29/snapchat-scores-unprecedented-deal-with-nbc-to-showcase-olympics|title=Snapchat Scores Unique Deal With NBC to Showcase Olympics|website=Bloomberg|accessdate=April 30, 2016}} In May 2016, as part of a campaign to promote ''[[X-Men: Apocalypse]]'', [[20th Century Fox]] paid for the entire array of lenses to be replaced by those based on characters from the ''[[X-Men]]'' series and films for a single day.{{cite web |first=Lauren |last=Johnson |title=20th Century Fox Buys First Snapchat Lens Takeover Ad |url=http://www.adweek.com/digital/twentieth-century-fox-buys-first-snapchat-lens-takeover-ad-171639/ |website=[[Adweek]] |publisher=Beringer Capital |date=May 23, 2016 |accessdate=June 20, 2017}} In July 2016, it was reported that Snapchat had submitted a [[patent]] application for the process of using an object recognition system to deliver sponsored filters based on objects seen in a camera view.{{cite web |first=James |last=Vincent |title=Snapchat applies for patent to serve ads by recognizing objects in your snaps |url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/7/18/12211292/snapchat-object-recognition-advertising |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=July 18, 2016 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}} Later that year, in Sep 2016, Snapchat released its first hardware product, called the Spectacles. Evan Spiegel, CEO of [[Snap Inc.]], called it “a toy” but saw it as an upside to freeing his app from smartphone cameras.{{Cite news|url=https://latestgadgets.tech/2016/09/24/snapchat-launches-camera-sunglasses/|title=Snapchat launches camera sunglasses, and they're very expensive • Latest Gadgets|date=September 24, 2016|work=Latest Gadgets|access-date=June 13, 2018|language=en-US}} In April 2017, ''[[Digiday]]'' reported that Snapchat would launch a self-service manager for advertising on the platform.{{cite web |first=Tanya |last=Dua |title=Snapchat is launching a self-serve platform for Snap ads |url=https://digiday.com/marketing/snapchat-launching-self-serve-platform-snap-ads/ |website=''[[Digiday]]'' |date=April 17, 2017 |accessdate=June 20, 2017}} The feature launched the following month, alongside news of a Snapchat Mobile Dashboard for tracking ad campaigns, set to roll out in June to select countries.{{cite web |first=Josh |last=Constine |title=Snapchat launches self-serve ad manager |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/05/04/snapchat-ad-manager/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=May 4, 2017 |accessdate=June 20, 2017}} Also in 2017, Snapchat introduced a "Snap to Store" advertising tool that lets companies using geostickers to track whether users buy their product or
